required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: SW-IMRT Versus ST-IMRT in the Treatment of Head and Neck Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Swallowing Sparing IMRT (SW-IMRT) Versus Standard Parotid Sparing IMRT (ST-IMRT) in the Treatment of Head and Neck Cancer

brief_summary.textblock: To clinically validate whether SW-IMRT actually reduce the occurrence of swallowing dysfunction as compared to ST-IMRT.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients are randomly assigned to either ST-IMRT or SW-IMRT.

primary_outcome.measure: Subjective assessment of the swallowing function (dysphagia) at regular intervals
primary_outcome.description: Subjective assessment of swallowing function (dysphagia) will be scored on a scale of 0 (no dysphagia) to 4 (life threatening consequences; urgent intervention indicated) each follow-up visit on the basis of National Cancer Institute Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events, version 4 (CTCAE 4).

primary_outcome.measure: Objective assessment of the swallowing function (dysphagia) at regular intervals
primary_outcome.description: Objective assessment of swallowing will be made by videofluoroscopy and scored by Dynamic Imaging Grade of swallowing toxicity scale (DIGEST) and will be scored on a scale of 0 (no dysphagia) to 4 (life threatening )

secondary_outcome.description: Clinical examination and Imaging will be done at regular interval to detect local or nodal recurrence

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with squamous cell carcinoma and requiring whole neck irradiation as a part of either definitive RT alone or in combination with chemotherapy or post-operative RT either alone or in combination with chemotherapy.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous radiotherapy to the head and neck region or prior malignancies, and/or distant metastases.
